div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, [February 23, 1901]
div1.p:
While the Mobile (Ala.) Register pro-
tests against a too hasty acceptance of
the theory that yellow fever is communi-
cated only through the medium of a mos-
quito bite, one Dr. James J. Walsh, writ-
ing in the New York Journal, is assuring
all creation--such being the size of the
Journal's circulation--that the theory is
without a flaw. The Register is published
in a town which up to 1880 had intimate
knowledge of yellow fever for nearly if
not quite half a century. Dr. Walsh is a
gentleman who, if we may base a judg-
ment upon his utterances, has never seen
half a dozen cases in all his professional
career.
To illustrate: The Mobile Register says:

“The most that can be said of the theory is
that it is possibly a true one. No exhaustive ex-
periment has been made--no experiment so thor-
ough as to demonstrate that the mosquito does
carry the infection, or that the mosquito is the
only carrier of the infection. We have taken the
trouble to examine the evidence, and can say with
assurance of speaking the truth that the experi-
ments do not prove anything whatever, except the
possibility that yellow fever is carried by the
insect.”

On the other hand, Dr. Walsh speaks
with all the confidence of an established
oracle:

“Yellow fever is distinctly a warm-weather dis-
ease. It always disappears with cold weather. In
this it is the exact contrary of smallpox, which
flourishes most virulently during continuous cold
weather. The first frost was always the signal
for the cessation of yellow fever in a locality, no
matter with what virulence the disease had been
raging beforehand. Malaria also disappears with
frost. We know now that the reason for this is
that the mosquito settles down into winter quar-
ters and no longer goes campaigning when cold
weather sets in. The new theory as to yellow
fever will explain its disappearance with the
frost.”

It is a fact, however, and one suscepti-
ble of easy demonstration, that “the first
frost” is not and never has been “the sig-
nal for the cessation of yellow fever.” It
is equally a fact that the mosquito does
not “settle down into winter quarters and
no longer goes campaigning when cold
weather sets in.” Both these propositions
are ridiculously untenable. Everybody
who has had the slightest experience of
yellow fever in such cities as New Or-
leans, Mobile, Pensacola, &c., knows that
the “first frost” has no effect upon yel-
low fever, except to quadruple the peril
of those who are its victims at the time.
The infection does not continue to
spread--indeed, it begins to contract--af-
ter the appearance of cold weather, but it
does not vanish, as Dr. Walsh fondly
imagines. On the contrary, during the
great epidemic of 1878 in New Orleans it
survived a dozen frosts, and there is an
authenticated case of a servant in the
residence of Col. John B. Lafitte, of that
city, who died December 26, having con-
tracted the disease on the 22d--after sev-
eral occurrences, not of frost, but of
freezing temperature. Nor is it true that
the New Orleans mosquito goes into win-
ter quarters and ceases campaigning
when the cold sets in. No matter how low
the mercury may fall outside, one has
only to warm his room to the point of
comfort in order to restore the little gray
house mosquito to regular midsummer
activity.

We quite agree with the esteemed Reg-
ister that the apostles of the new yellow
fever gospel have still much to prove if
they would greatly swell the number of
its followers. It is a fact, however, that
we devoutly wish things were as they be-
lieve. What a blessing it would be to see
the last of the barbarous inland quaran-
tine machinery--including the shotgun
and the railroad wrecker--and to hail as
its successor the harmless mosquito net
by night and the evil-smelling anoint-
ment by day!
